text: [Music]
my work which is divided into three
categories so I teach and I do
consulting work and I actually am also a
therapist and I would put the group
relations work that we do that the three
of us have done together into sort of
the organizational and the teaching
category same time and so I feel as
though the group relations work has been
just in some ways the the core of the
way that I look at organizations the way
that I understand even individuals
because every individual is also
existing inside of a system so that in
some ways integrates all of the other
parts and I feel quite dedicated to it
have been doing it for a really really
long time
because I feel as though it opens up and
makes available what is otherwise
unspeakable in other settings and it's
one of the very few places where that's
true what I find in in the classroom is
that I have these challenges and they
the basic challenge that I run into is
that my students have intellectual
awareness but they don't have a
practical awareness of how any of this
works the group relations orientation
provides a lens that has affected me so
profoundly in terms of my own being that
I want to bring that and make that
available to other people but what I
also find and that's the key is that
then when I use it professionally than
what begins to happen is it informs the
interventions that I do it informs the
way that I relate to others and it
provides an understanding of what's
going on just below the surface
and and then there's this opportunity to
bring it forward
and without that it doesn't all
integrate and for me it's important that
it all comes together in a meaningful
way I see the intellectual the practical
academic and administrative integrating
and powerful and one
always in my profession and the lives of
people that I touch so in my role as a
higher education administrator I am in
multiple groups faculty staff students
and thinking about the system as a whole
for example at the University of
California San Diego and in working with
leadership fellows in the community it's
a bit of academic thinking about
community and social and political
concerns and with group relations work
and thinking about leadership and
authority specifically as my colleagues
have said it is exploring that which is
hidden that which is more covert that in
our practical community academic life we
are not necessarily accessing but
through leadership studies with these
lenses we're able to empower others and
enlighten in a way that I don't think in
our public discourse or academic
discourse we're doing so I'm pleased to
really be in all those spheres to use
the lenses from each other place to
inform the current situation
